Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I developed my Spanish grammar greatly, specifically in the area of subjunctive, past and present, and if clauses. I also developed my vocabulary and fluidness when speaking in Spanish.
After this semester I definitely saw an improvement in my conversational skills especially because of the discusses that were held after readings.
Conversation, reading, writing, and critical thinking in Spanish. Probably the best Spanish conversation course I've taken so far.
Improved my Spanish speaking, writing, and reading skills.
Spanish language, grammar, culture, etc.
I developed my reading comprehension and vocabulary.  I also gained some grammatical knowledge, but my speaking skills remained pretty stagnant.
I gained proficiency in Spanish, particularly in using subjunctive tenses.
A lot of grammar.

I think the short stories were very interesting and our discussions on them helped me improve my oral abilities, but sometimes the class seemed too rote in that we did the same assignments for almost every reading. I think there could have been more variety.

I think compared to L3 -- this course is less organized. For L3, it was really clear what we should study for each test and what the objective of certain lessons were -- but this class was overall less organized. It was still fairly structured though -- and improved our grammar by repeatedly testing the same concepts. I think it could be improved though by more clarity on what to study and more flexible rubrics on grading (often times points are deducted when you demonstrated correct thinking due to rigid rubrics).
I think there should be more activities and applications of grammar during class and in class. I also do not think vhl is a great platform to learn skills.

This course was great for discussions and I felt that all the assessments were fair. Mostly, I was very engaged in this course. The second oral presentation seemed very daunting, because it asked us to summarize incredibly broad topics ("Mexican Political Issues in the 1950s," for example), of which we had no previous knowledge or coursework. I also strongly suggest that we stop watching "Fotonovela." It's inane and unfunny.
well-organized, less homework than previous classes (which is a positive as you could focus better on each assignment), great texts

This course was extremely well organized and Maripaz was always looking for ways to help her students improve. There were plenty of exercises and grammar activities to reinforce lessons, as well as interesting questions.

Lots of focus on vocabulary and reading.  The stories are interesting and the assignments are fair.  The organization of the class is definitely a strong point.  That being said, there is very little development of on-the-fly speaking ability.

Definitely a big focus on grammar. The weaknesses were the methods the material was presented. It was all power points or call and response on worksheets which favors a particle type of learner. I was not one of those learners and therefore struggled heavily and unnecessarily with the way the material was presented. I'd highly consider the ways Maripaz structures her classes, as the way they are done now favors a certain type of gregarious student with a certain skill.
Yes, I think this class was important in furthering my Spanish education.
Yes.
I think this is a good course to improve grammar -- and with a good instructor, it can be a good experience.
Yes I definitely recommend this course.
Yes, it's a good course!
Standard L4 course, but better by far than L2 and L3
Yes. Prof. is very good at teaching Spanish. I think I learned more in this class than any other semester of Spanish I've taken.
Yes.
Most people will take this class to fulfill the requirement, and I think it does fine at that.
Yes, I enjoyed it and thought it improved my Spanish.
No. I found it repetitive and a lot of memorization. Learning a language can be fun, but this course was not.
